conclusion: The problem involves determining the magnitude of the electric force experienced by a small ball with charge +q and mass m when it reaches point B in a tube system influenced by two fixed charges +Q and -Q.
The electric force is the sum of the Coulomb forces exerted by the charges +Q and -Q on the small ball.
The Coulomb force between two point charges is given by the equation F = k |q1 q2| / r^2, where k is the Coulomb constant, q1 and q2 are the charges, and r is the distance between the charges.
The Coulomb force exerted by the charge +Q on the small ball is F_Coulomb = k |q| Q / r^2.
The Coulomb force exerted by the charge -Q on the small ball is F_Coulomb = k |q| Q / r^2.
The combined force of the Coulomb forces from +Q and -Q is F_combined = F_Coulomb + F_Coulomb.
The combined force is F_combined = 2 × (k |q| Q / r^2).
The distance r between the small ball and each charge is r = L / 2, where L is the side length of the equilateral triangle formed by points M, N, and B.
Substituting r = L / 2 into the equation for F_combined gives F_combined = 2 × (k |q| Q / (L / 2)^2).
Simplifying the equation gives F_combined = 2 × (k |q| Q / (L^2 / 4)).
Further simplification gives F_combined = (8k |q| Q) / L^2.
The magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball when it reaches point B is F_combined = (8k |q| Q) / L^2.
